intro: Gnaphalodes amphibola, commonly known as the water dock, is a flowering plant native to parts of Africa and Asia. It belongs to the Asteraceae family, which includes daisies and sunflowers, and is characterized by its composite flower heads. The plant typically grows in wet or marshy areas, thriving in humid environments. Its leaves are broad and fleshy, adapted to retain moisture, while its flowers are small and yellow, arranged in dense clusters. Gnaphalodes amphibola is often used in traditional medicine for its purported health benefits.
